comments:
I have implemented a command line build option for our users that attempts to
headlessly build your Eclipse projects.  This is very useful as it allows our
users to build their projects using my custom builder from a script, etc.  It
was originally thought this would be extra-cool because properly implementing a
headless builder would give our users the added benefit that all of their
external tool-based builders they have set up on their projects would also be
run, and the build would be *exactly* as if they had run the build from within
the IDE (Eclipse).

However, it was soon apparent that as users started taking advantage of this
that the external tool-based builders were not being executed at all.  Further
investigation reveals that the builder is being called by the BuildManager, but
it is simply crashing when it tries to load UI code from the Debug UI plugin. 
The log messages are as follows (all of the extra stack traces having to do with
failing to load the BreakpointOrganizer, starting the debug.ui plugin, etc. have
been omitted):

So it appears that the external tools builder gets some information by basically
calling methods contained in the actual Tabs of the launch configuration UI
pages, essentially making the external tool build/launch framework non-headless
friendly.  This is a major hole in my opinion.  I think that any builders should
be able to be run in headless mode.  Isn't the CDT also trying to implement
command line builds in headless mode?

Is there any way I can work around this problem?  Currently I cannot see a way
around this.

The current implementation of external tool builders does not work in headless 
mode. It has always been a UI component.

This would require a fairly large rework and the creation of a new headless 
plugin (org.eclipse.core.externaltools?).

This is not on the plan for 3.2

Gah!  Is it really that big of a job to make it headless-friendly?  I mean, all
of the information to launch is persisted in a .launch file, right - why do you
need to go through the UI to read those values back?  I guess the other major UI
thing is registering with the launch manager, creating a Process, etc.  Hmmm...

If something was done in this area and submitted as a patch, would it be
considered for 3.2?

A patch would allow the changes to be considered for 3.2.

Another major challenge is to support the backwards compatibility of all 
existing launch files...
*** Bug 162405 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
